prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context
Policy Considerations Governing the Protection of Intellectual Property

head.headtext: Means for Protecting Intellectual Property—Prevention of unfair competition (as in protection of confidential information)

para.paratext: The laws of intellectual property seek to reward inventiveness while at the same time eliminating unfair competition.[1] This is all the more important in the case of confidential information where protection is not accomplished by state intervention and copying is not precluded by the laws of copyright and patent.[2] Confidential business information is protected by invoking the existing laws of property, contract and tort, and/or the laws of breach of confidence.
Kewanee Oil Co. v. Bicron Corp., 416 U.S. 470 (1974).
Copyright Act, s. 63; Kewanee Oil Co. v. Bicron Corp., 416 U.S. 470 (1974); Warman International Ltd. v. Envirotech Australia Pty. Ltd. (1986), 67 A.L.R. 253 (F.C.), at pp. 275-6.
